person.persName: William Lowndes Yancey (Montgomery, Alabama, attorney and “fire-eater”)

body.p: Montgomery, Alabama, attorney and “fire-eater.” Warren County, Georgia native. Son of Caroline Bird Yancey and Benjamin Cudworth Yancey. Married Sarah Caroline Earle in Greenville, South Carolina in c.1835. Father of Benjamin C. Yancey, George E. Yancey, Mary Elizabeth Yancey, Ella Bird Yancey, William E. Yancey, Dalton H. Yancey, and Goodloe H. Yancey. Educated at Yates Polytechnic Institute in Chittenango, New York; Bennington Academy in Vermont; and Lenox Academy in Massachusetts c.1820-1830. Attended Williams College in Williamstown, Massachusetts from 1831 to 1832. Editor of Greenville Mountaineer in Greenville, South Carolina c.1833. Editor of Cahaba Democrat in Cahaba, Alabama c.1839. Passed Alabama state bar c.1843. Member of United States House of Representatives from Alabama’s 3rd District from December 2, 1844 to September 1, 1846. Law partner with John Elmore in Montgomery, Alabama c.1847. Helped organized Southern Rights Party in Montgomery, Alabama in 1850. Instrumental in Alabama’s push for secession from the United States between 1858 and 1861. Served as an Ambassador to England and France for Jefferson Davis in 1861. Served as a Senator in the Confederate Congress in 1862.
